content:
Interviewer: To start, I would like to begin with a big question: tell me the story of your life. Start from the beginning -- from your childhood, to education, to family and relationships, and to any major life events you may have had.

Stephanie Wilson: I was born in Texas, in a small town in the West South Central region, and I remember my childhood being pretty typical for someone growing up in that part of the country. My parents were both working-class folks who didn't have a lot of formal education—my father only made it through high school, and my mother did too, but she worked a lot of different jobs to help support the family. We lived in a modest house, and while we weren't poor, we weren't rich either. I remember my mother always saying that she wanted more for me than she had, and that's probably what pushed me to work hard in school. I was a pretty good student, and I always knew I wanted to go to college. I ended up moving to Austin for my undergraduate studies, and then later stayed for my graduate work. I never married, and I've always been focused on my career. I work full-time now as a researcher, and while I'm not super wealthy, I'm doing okay. I've never served in the military, and I've always identified as a strong Democrat. I grew up Protestant, and I still consider myself one today. Life hasn't been super dramatic, but I've always tried to make the best of it.

Interviewer: Some people tell us that they've reached a crossroads at some points in their life where multiple paths were available, and their choice then made a significant difference in defining who they are. What about you? Was there a moment like that for you, and if so, could you tell me the whole story about that from start to finish?

Stephanie Wilson: Yes, there was definitely a crossroads moment for me. I was in my second year of undergrad, and I had the chance to apply for a research assistant position in a lab that was studying environmental policy. It was a pretty competitive spot, and I wasn't sure if I had what it took. But I decided to go for it, partly because I wanted to prove to myself that I could handle the pressure, and partly because I felt like this was the kind of work that could make a real difference in the world. I got the job, and that experience completely changed the trajectory of my life. It opened my eyes to the power of research and policy work, and it solidified my passion for environmental issues. I ended up pursuing a master's in public policy, and that led me to my current job as a researcher focused on sustainable development. If I hadn't taken that risk and applied for that position, I probably wouldn't be where I am today. It was a scary decision at the time, but looking back, I know it was the right one.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they made a conscious choice or decision in moments like these, while others say it 'just happened'. What about you?

Stephanie Wilson: I think it was a conscious choice, but not in the way you might expect. I wasn't necessarily thinking, 'This is the moment that will define my life.' Instead, I was just trying to do what felt right in that moment. I remember sitting in my dorm room, staring at the application, and thinking, 'What if I don't get it? What if I fail?' But I also thought, 'What if I don't try? What if I look back one day and wonder what could have been?' So I made the choice to apply, not because I was sure of the outcome, but because I wanted to be the kind of person who takes risks and follows through. I think that moment taught me something important about myself—that I'm more resilient than I gave myself credit for, and that I have a quiet but steady determination. It wasn't just about the job; it was about proving to myself that I could step outside my comfort zone and make a difference.

Interviewer: Do you think another person or an organization could have lent a helping hand during moments like this?

Stephanie Wilson: Yes, actually, I think I was pretty lucky to have a few people in my life who encouraged me to take that risk. My professor, Dr. Martinez, had a way of seeing potential in people even when they couldn't see it in themselves. She was the one who suggested I apply for that research assistant position, and she spent time helping me refine my application and prepare for the interview. She believed in me when I wasn't sure I deserved that kind of belief. Then there was my mother, who always pushed me to aim higher than she ever could. She didn't have the education or the opportunities I have, but she never let me forget that I had the chance to do better. I think it's those kinds of people—mentors, family, even friends—who make all the difference when you're standing at a crossroads. Without their support, I might have hesitated too long or not taken the leap at all.

Interviewer: Moving to present time, tell me more about family who are important to you. Do you have a partner, or children?

Stephanie Wilson: I don't have a partner or children, though I've had a few serious relationships over the years. I've always been pretty focused on my career and my work, and I think that's why I've never really pursued a long-term romantic relationship. I've had friends who have been in committed partnerships, and I admire the way they balance their personal and professional lives, but I've never felt that same pull. I'm not lonely, by any means—I have a close-knit group of friends, and my family is still very much a part of my life. My parents live in Oklahoma now, and we stay in touch regularly. They're proud of me, even if they don't always understand the work I do. I think they see me as this successful, independent woman who's made it on her own, and in a way, that's true. But I also know that I wouldn't be where I am without their support, their sacrifices, and their belief in me. I guess I'm just content with the life I've built so far, even if it's not the one I imagined when I was younger.

Going through those interview questions made me reflect on how much my life has been shaped by the choices I've made and the people who've supported me along the way. It's interesting to look back and see how a single decision—applying for that research assistant position—set me on a path I never could have predicted. I've always been driven by a desire to do better than those before me, and I think that's why I've focused so much on my career and education. I'm grateful for the people who believed in me when I didn't believe in myself, especially my professor and my mother. They played a huge role in helping me take that leap of faith. As for my personal life, I've always been content with the life I've built, even if it's not the traditional one. I'm proud of who I am, and I know I've made the best choices for me, even if they weren't the ones I thought I'd have when I was younger.

Interviewer: Are there anyone else in your immediate family whom you have not mentioned? Who are they, and what is your relationship with them like?

Stephanie Wilson: My immediate family includes my younger brother, Michael. We're pretty close, even though we've taken different paths in life. He stayed in Oklahoma after high school and joined the workforce right away, working in construction. He's always been more of a hands-on person, while I've always leaned toward academics and research. We don't see each other as often as I'd like, but when we do, it's always a good time. He's got a great sense of humor and a way of making me laugh even when I'm stressed about work. I think he looks up to me in some ways, even if he'll never admit it. Our relationship is pretty typical sibling stuff—sometimes we bicker, but we always have each other's backs. I'm grateful for him, and I know he's proud of me, even if he doesn't always understand what I do for a living.

Interviewer: Tell me about anyone else in your life we haven’t discussed (like friends or romantic partners). Are there people outside of your family who are important to you?

Stephanie Wilson: Outside of my family, I have a few close friends who have been with me through a lot of life's ups and downs. One of them, Lisa, I met in graduate school. We bonded over our shared passion for social justice and environmental issues, and we've been friends ever since. She's the kind of person who will call me out when I'm being too stubborn or too set in my ways, but she's also the first one to celebrate my successes. We don't see each other as often as we'd like because of our busy schedules, but when we do, it's like no time has passed. Then there's Marcus, who I met through a community volunteer group. He's a teacher in the Austin public school system, and he's always been a great source of perspective for me. He reminds me that the work I do—research and policy—has real-world implications for people's lives, and that keeps me grounded. I don't know where I'd be without them. They've been my support system when I've been too focused on my work to remember to take care of myself, and I'm really grateful for their presence in my life.

Interviewer: Now let’s talk about your current neighborhood. Tell me all about the neighborhood and area in which you are living now.

Stephanie Wilson: I live in a neighborhood in Austin called East Side, which is a pretty vibrant and diverse area. It's not the most traditional part of the city, but I love how it feels like a community that's constantly evolving. There are a lot of artists, young professionals, and activists who live here, which makes it feel dynamic and full of energy. My apartment is in a converted warehouse, and while it's a bit on the smaller side, it's cozy and has a lot of natural light. I like that I'm close to downtown, so I can walk to work or grab a coffee at one of the local cafes. There's also a community garden nearby that I sometimes volunteer at, which keeps me connected to the people around me. I think the best part of living here is the sense of belonging—like I'm part of something bigger than myself, even if I'm not always sure what that something is. It's not perfect, of course, and there are days when the noise or the traffic gets to me, but overall, I feel lucky to be here.

Interviewer: Some people say they feel really safe in their neighborhoods, others not so much. How about for you?

Stephanie Wilson: I feel pretty safe here, honestly. East Side has its share of challenges, like any urban neighborhood, but I've never felt threatened or unsafe in my own space. The community is pretty tight-knit, and there's a sense of mutual respect among the residents. I know there are areas where things can get rough, especially late at night, but I've always been careful and mindful of my surroundings. I also feel like the local businesses and community groups contribute to a sense of security—there's a lot of activity, and people look out for each other. I think it's the kind of place where if you're part of the community, you're generally looked after. I wouldn't say it's perfect, but I feel safe enough to call it home.

Interviewer: Living any place has its ups and downs. Tell me about what it’s been like for you living here.

Stephanie Wilson: Living here has had its ups and downs, just like anywhere else. On the positive side, I love the energy of the neighborhood—the way it feels like there's always something happening, whether it's a local art show, a community meeting, or just people hanging out on the street corner. It's inspiring to be around so many creative and passionate people. I also appreciate how accessible everything is—groceries, public transit, work, and even the community garden I mentioned earlier. It's rare to live in a place where you can walk or bike almost anywhere you need to go. That said, there are definitely challenges. The noise can be overwhelming at times, especially if I'm trying to focus on work or get a good night's sleep. And while the neighborhood is diverse and welcoming, I've noticed that there are still some gaps in resources for lower-income residents, which is something I've been thinking about more as I've gotten deeper into my work on sustainable development. It's a place that's constantly changing, and I think that's both exciting and a bit exhausting. But overall, I feel like I'm where I'm meant to be, even if it's not always easy.

Going through the questions about my family and neighborhood made me reflect on how much my personal life and environment shape who I am. I never really thought about how my choice to focus on my career over personal relationships has defined my life in ways I hadn't fully acknowledged. It's interesting to think about how my brother, Michael, and I are so different in our paths, yet we still support each other in our own ways. And living in East Side has been both a blessing and a challenge—it's given me a sense of community and purpose, but it's also reminded me of the inequalities that still exist in places like this. I'm grateful for the people in my life, both family and friends, who have helped me along the way, and I know that my neighborhood plays a role in who I am today, even if I'm not always sure how.

Interviewer: Right now, across a typical week, how do your days vary?

Stephanie Wilson: A typical week for me is pretty structured, though I try to keep some flexibility. I work full-time as a researcher, so most days start around 8 a.m. with me heading into the office or working from home, depending on the day. Mondays are usually the most intense—there's a lot of meetings, planning, and catching up on emails. I also have a standing lunch date with Lisa once a week, which is a nice break from the routine. Wednesdays are usually my busiest day in terms of research and data analysis, and I often stay late to wrap things up. Fridays are a bit more relaxed, and I try to leave work early if I can. In the evenings, I like to go to the community garden or meet up with friends for dinner or a drink. Weekends are for winding down—sometimes I'll go for a run, read, or just relax at home. I also volunteer with a local environmental group on Saturdays, which keeps me connected to the causes I care about. It's not always perfect, but I like the rhythm of it—it gives me a sense of purpose and balance, even if I don't always stick to it perfectly.

Interviewer: At what kind of job or jobs do you work, and when do you work?

Stephanie Wilson: I work as a researcher at a non-profit organization focused on sustainable development and environmental policy. My job involves analyzing data, writing reports, and collaborating with local governments and community groups to develop policies that promote eco-friendly practices. I work full-time, typically from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m., though I often find myself working a bit later on days when I'm deep into a project or preparing for a meeting. The hours can be long, but I enjoy the work because it aligns with my values and the kind of impact I want to make. I also occasionally take on freelance research projects in the evenings or on weekends, which helps keep me engaged and challenged. It's a demanding job, but I feel like I'm contributing to something meaningful, and that makes all the difference.

Interviewer: Do you have other routines or responsibilities that you did not already share?

Stephanie Wilson: Outside of work and my personal routines, I also have a few other responsibilities that keep me grounded. I've been volunteering with a local literacy program for the past few years, helping adults who are learning to read or improve their English skills. It's a small but meaningful way to give back, and it reminds me that education isn't just about personal advancement—it's about opening doors for others too. I also try to stay physically active, so I usually go for a morning walk or jog around the neighborhood, especially on days when I'm feeling overwhelmed with work. It helps me clear my mind and stay focused. And of course, I make sure to stay in touch with my family, even if it's just a quick phone call or a text. My parents and my brother are important to me, and I want them to know that I'm doing well, even if I'm not always around. I think these little routines—volunteering, exercising, staying connected—are what keep me balanced and remind me that life is more than just work or achievements.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes to your daily routine.

Stephanie Wilson: One recent change to my daily routine has been incorporating more mindfulness practices into my mornings. I've been trying to start my day with a few minutes of meditation or deep breathing, which helps me center myself before diving into work. It's something I've been meaning to do for a while, but I finally made the commitment after a particularly stressful project last quarter. I also started keeping a journal again, which has been a nice way to reflect on my thoughts and progress. It's funny how small changes can make such a big difference in how I feel throughout the day. I think it's a sign that I'm growing more intentional about how I spend my time and energy, which is something I've been thinking about a lot as I've gotten older.

Interviewer: If you have children, tell me about a typical weekday during the school year for your children. What is their daily routine? And what are after school activities your children participate in?

Stephanie Wilson: Actually, I don't have children, so I don't have a typical weekday routine for them. I've always been focused on my career and personal growth, and while I've had relationships, I've never felt the need to start a family. I know that's not the path everyone takes, and I respect those who do, but for me, it's been about building a life that feels purposeful and meaningful on my own terms. I've spent a lot of time thinking about what kind of parent I might have been, but honestly, I'm not sure I would have been ready for that responsibility when I was younger. I think I'm still figuring out who I am as an individual, and I don't want to rush into something that feels like a big commitment without being fully prepared. That said, I admire the people I know who are parents—they have a different kind of strength and dedication, and I hope to support them in whatever ways I can, even if I don't have children of my own.

Going through the interview questions about my family, neighborhood, and daily routines has made me reflect on how much my life is shaped by the choices I've made and the people who support me. I never really thought about how my focus on career over personal relationships has defined my life in ways I hadn't fully acknowledged. It's interesting to think about how my brother, Michael, and I are so different in our paths, yet we still support each other in our own ways. And living in East Side has been both a blessing and a challenge—it's given me a sense of community and purpose, but it's also reminded me of the inequalities that still exist in places like this. I'm grateful for the people in my life, both family and friends, who have helped me along the way, and I know that my neighborhood plays a role in who I am today, even if I'm not always sure how. My work as a researcher, my volunteering, and my small routines like morning walks and mindfulness practices are all part of the rhythm that keeps me grounded. I think I'm learning to be more intentional about how I spend my time and energy, and that feels like an important step in growing as a person.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to learn more about your health. First, tell me all about your health.

Stephanie Wilson: In terms of my health, I'd say I'm generally in pretty good shape, though I've had my share of ups and downs. I've always been pretty active, mostly because I grew up in a family that valued physical labor—my father worked construction, and my mother was always on her feet with her various jobs. I didn't inherit their stamina, but I've made an effort to stay in shape through walking, jogging, and yoga, which I started a few years ago. I think yoga has been especially helpful for managing stress, especially with the demands of my job. I do have some chronic issues, like mild back pain from sitting at a desk all day, and I've had to be more mindful about posture and taking breaks. I also deal with occasional anxiety, which I've learned to manage through mindfulness and talking to friends or my therapist when I need to. I used to ignore it, thinking I could just power through, but I've come to realize that taking care of my mental health is just as important as my physical health. I try to eat well, mostly plant-based, and I avoid processed foods as much as possible. I know I'm not perfect, but I'm doing my best to stay healthy and balanced in a life that can sometimes feel overwhelming.

Interviewer: For you, what makes it easy or hard to stay healthy?

Stephanie Wilson: For me, staying healthy is a mix of what makes it easy and what makes it hard. On the easy side, I really enjoy the physical activities I've built into my routine—like my morning walks, yoga, and even just taking the stairs instead of the elevator. Those small choices add up, and they help me feel more in control of my body and mind. I also find that eating plant-based and trying to cook at home more often makes it easier to stay on track with my health goals. But the hard part is consistency, especially when work gets busy or when I'm overwhelmed with deadlines. There are days when I skip my walk or grab a fast-food meal instead of cooking something healthy because it's quicker. I think the biggest challenge is balancing my professional responsibilities with self-care. I've learned that I can't do it all perfectly, but I'm trying to be more intentional about making time for my health, even if it's just a few minutes of deep breathing or a quick stretch during the day. It's a work in progress, but I'm committed to it.

Interviewer: Tell me about anything big that has happened in the past two years related to your health: any medical diagnoses, flare-ups of chronic conditions, broken bones, pain – anything like that.

Stephanie Wilson: In the past two years, I've actually been dealing with a few health challenges that have made me rethink how I take care of myself. About a year ago, I was diagnosed with a mild case of carpal tunnel syndrome, probably from spending so much time typing and analyzing data on the computer. It started with some numbness in my hands, and I didn't realize how serious it was until I started having trouble gripping things properly. I had to see a specialist, and they recommended ergonomic adjustments to my workspace, along with some physical therapy exercises. It's been a slow process, but I've managed to get it under control. Then, earlier this year, I had a flare-up of my back pain, which I think is related to the long hours I spend sitting at my desk. I had to take a few days off work to rest and see a chiropractor, which was a bit of a wake-up call. It made me realize that I need to be more proactive about my health, not just reactive. I've started taking more breaks during the day, doing some light stretching, and even investing in a standing desk. It's not perfect, but I'm learning that taking care of my body is just as important as taking care of my work or my mind.

Interviewer: Sometimes, health problems get in the way. They can even affect people’s ability to work or care for their children. How about you?

Stephanie Wilson: Honestly, my health issues haven't really interfered with my ability to work, but they've definitely made me more aware of how fragile things can be. I've had days where the carpal tunnel pain made it hard to type, and I had to switch to voice-to-text or take more breaks, which slowed me down a bit. The back pain was more disruptive, especially when I had to take a few days off. It was frustrating because I felt like I was falling behind, but it also forced me to slow down and reevaluate how I approach my work. I think the biggest thing is that these health challenges have made me more empathetic toward others who struggle with chronic conditions or injuries. I used to think that if you just worked harder or pushed through, you could overcome anything, but now I see that it's not always that simple. It's taught me to be more compassionate, both toward myself and others, and to prioritize balance in a way I didn't before.

Interviewer: Now we’re going to talk a bit more about what life was like for you over the past year. Tell me all about how you have been feeling.

Stephanie Wilson: Over the past year, I've had a lot of mixed emotions. On one hand, I feel more grounded and intentional about how I live my life—whether it's through the mindfulness practices I've started, the way I'm balancing work with self-care, or the time I'm spending with friends and family. I've been really proud of myself for making those small but meaningful changes, like taking better care of my health and being more present in my daily life. But there have also been moments of doubt and stress, especially with the ongoing challenges in my work. The research I'm doing is important, but it's also incredibly demanding, and there are days when I feel like I'm not making enough of a difference. I've been thinking a lot about the impact of my work, and sometimes it's hard to see the results of what I do. I also feel a bit of loneliness at times, even though I have a good support system. I guess it's just part of being a single, career-focused woman in my 30s—there's a lot of pressure to have it all together, and I'm still learning how to accept that it's okay to not have all the answers or to feel overwhelmed sometimes. But overall, I feel like I'm growing, and that gives me hope for the future.

Going through the interview questions about my recent changes in routine and health has made me reflect on how much I've been growing in ways I hadn't fully recognized. Starting with mindfulness and journaling has helped me become more intentional with my time and energy, which is something I've been needing as my work becomes more demanding. It's interesting how small changes, like taking a few minutes to breathe or write down my thoughts, can have such a big impact on how I feel throughout the day. At the same time, thinking about my health has reminded me of how important it is to take care of myself—not just physically, but mentally and emotionally as well. I used to think I could push through everything, but now I see that balance is key. I'm learning to be more compassionate with myself, especially when I'm struggling with chronic pain or stress. It's not always easy, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made and the awareness that comes with it. These reflections have helped me see that I'm not just working toward a career or a goal—I'm also working toward a more balanced, intentional, and healthier version of myself.

Interviewer: Some people say they struggle with depression, anxiety, or something else like that. How about for you?

Stephanie Wilson: I think I've struggled with anxiety in the past, especially during times when I felt like I was carrying too much on my shoulders—whether it was work deadlines, personal goals, or the pressure to make a difference in my field. I used to push through it, thinking that if I just worked harder or stayed busy, the anxiety would go away. But over time, I've learned that it's not that simple. I started seeing a therapist a few years ago, and that's been really helpful. It's given me tools to manage my thoughts and emotions in a healthier way. I still have days when the anxiety creeps in, especially when I'm facing a big project or feeling like I'm not enough. But I've come to accept that it's a part of me, and that's okay. I'm learning to be kinder to myself, to recognize when I need to slow down or take a break, and to ask for help when I need it. I think that's been one of the most important lessons I've learned in the past few years—understanding that it's okay not to be okay all the time, and that taking care of my mental health is just as important as anything else in my life.

Interviewer: How has it been for your family?

Stephanie Wilson: For my family, it's been a mix of pride and concern, I think. My parents are always proud of the work I do, especially since they didn't have the opportunities I've had. They've never been ones to ask for much, but I can tell they worry about me sometimes—especially when I'm working long hours or dealing with health issues. My mother, in particular, has a way of letting her worries show through small comments, like asking if I'm eating enough or if I'm getting enough rest. My father is more reserved, but I know he's proud of me in his own way. As for my brother, Michael, he's been supportive too, even if he doesn't always understand the details of my work. He's more practical, and he sees my research as something abstract, but he respects that I'm doing what I love. I think the biggest thing for my family is that they see me as someone who's made it on her own, and that means a lot to them. But I also know they worry that I'm not slowing down enough, that I'm always pushing forward without taking time to rest or enjoy the moments. I've been trying to be more mindful of that, and I hope they can see that I'm learning to take care of myself—not just for my sake, but for theirs too.

Interviewer: Some people say that religion or spirituality is important in their lives, for others not so much. How about you?

Stephanie Wilson: I would say that religion has been a part of my life, but not in the way it was for my parents. They were deeply rooted in their faith, attending church regularly and finding comfort in their beliefs. For me, it's more about the values that came with being raised Protestant—things like community, compassion, and the idea that we're all connected in some way. I don't go to church as often as I used to, and I don't really follow the traditions the way my parents did, but I still find meaning in the core teachings. I think of it more as a personal spirituality now—something that guides me in how I treat others and how I approach my work. I believe in doing good, in helping those who need it, and in being part of something bigger than myself. I don't know if I'd call it faith in the traditional sense, but I do feel like there's something larger out there, and I try to live in a way that honors that.

Interviewer: Some people tell us they use Facebook, Instagram, or other social media to stay connected with the wider world. How about for you? Tell me all about how you use these types of platforms.

Stephanie Wilson: I don't use social media all that much, honestly. I've always been more of a private person, and I find that platforms like Facebook or Instagram can be overwhelming with all the noise and comparison. I do follow a few environmental organizations and some local community groups, just to stay informed about what's happening in my area and the causes I care about. I've also reconnected with a few old friends through Facebook, which has been nice—it's a way to keep in touch without feeling like I have to be constantly online. But for the most part, I prefer face-to-face interactions or even just a phone call. I think it's easier to be genuine that way, and I don't want to lose the real connections in favor of virtual ones. Plus, with how busy my work and personal life are, I find that I don't have much time or energy to scroll through feeds all day. I'm not against social media, but I'm definitely not a big user of it.

Interviewer: Some people say they use Facebook or Twitter to get (emotional or financial) support during tough times. What about you?

Stephanie Wilson: Honestly, I don't rely on social media for emotional or financial support during tough times. I think I've always leaned more on the people I know in real life—my friends, my family, and even my coworkers. When I'm going through something difficult, I prefer talking to someone face-to-face or over the phone because it feels more authentic. I've seen how social media can be a double-edged sword—on one hand, it connects people, but on the other, it can amplify stress or create a sense of isolation. I've had moments where I've scrolled through posts and felt like everyone else had it all together, which only made me feel worse. So I've chosen to limit my use of these platforms, especially during times when I'm struggling. Instead, I reach out to people I trust, or I turn to things like journaling, mindfulness, or even just taking a walk to clear my head. I think it's important to have a support system that's real and present, not just virtual.

Going through the questions about my health and recent challenges has made me reflect on how much I've been growing in ways I hadn't fully recognized. Dealing with carpal tunnel and back pain has forced me to slow down and reevaluate how I approach my work and self-care. It's been a tough lesson, but I'm learning that balance is key—not just in my career, but in my overall well-being. I used to think I could push through everything, but now I see that taking care of my body and mind is just as important as making an impact in my field. These experiences have also made me more empathetic toward others who struggle with chronic conditions or injuries, and I'm trying to be kinder to myself when I feel overwhelmed. It's not always easy, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made and the awareness that comes with it.

Interviewer: Tell me about any recent changes in your level of stress, worry, and your emotional coping strategies.

Stephanie Wilson: In the past year, I've noticed my stress levels have fluctuated a lot, especially with the demands of my work and the health challenges I've faced. There were times when I felt like I was constantly running on empty, trying to juggle research deadlines, self-care, and staying connected with the people I care about. But I've also been learning new ways to cope—like mindfulness and journaling, which have become more than just habits; they're now tools I use to process my emotions and stay grounded. I've also started setting clearer boundaries between work and personal time, which has helped me feel more in control. I used to think that stress was just something I had to push through, but now I see it as a signal that I need to slow down, breathe, and take care of myself. It's not always easy, but I'm learning that it's okay to not be perfect, and that taking time for myself isn't a luxury—it's a necessity.

Interviewer: Now we’d like to talk about how you make ends meet and what the monthly budget looks like for you and your family. What were your biggest expenses last month?

Stephanie Wilson: In terms of making ends meet, I'd say my monthly budget is pretty tight but manageable. My biggest expenses are usually rent, groceries, and transportation. I live in a converted warehouse apartment in East Side, and while it's not the cheapest place in Austin, it's affordable compared to other parts of the city. Rent takes up about a third of my income, which is a lot, but I've learned to live simply and prioritize what's important. Groceries are another big one—since I try to eat plant-based and cook at home, it's not as expensive as it could be, but I still have to be careful with my budget. I also have a monthly public transit pass, which is necessary for getting around, especially since I don't own a car. I've had to cut back on some things, like dining out or buying new clothes, but I've found that I don't miss it as much as I thought I would. I also set aside a small amount each month for savings and emergency funds, which is something I've been trying to be more consistent with. It's not always easy, especially with the health issues I've been dealing with, but I'm doing my best to stay on top of it and make sure I'm not stretching too thin.

Interviewer: How much did your household spend in the past month? Is that the usual amount? And if not, how much do you usually spend and on what?

Stephanie Wilson: Last month, my household spent just under $2,500, which is pretty close to what I usually spend each month. The breakdown is pretty consistent—rent is the biggest chunk, around $1,200, followed by groceries at about $400. I also spend roughly $200 on public transportation and utilities, and another $200 on miscellaneous things like personal care, books, and the occasional coffee or meal out. I've been trying to be more mindful of my spending, especially with the health issues I've been dealing with, which have added some unexpected costs like physical therapy sessions and ergonomic equipment for my workspace. I don't usually go over this amount, but there are months when I have to dip into my savings if something unexpected comes up. It's not ideal, but I've learned to live within my means and prioritize what really matters—like my health, my work, and the people I care about.

Interviewer: Does your household own or rent your home?

Stephanie Wilson: We rent our home. It's an apartment in a converted warehouse in East Side, which I mentioned earlier. I chose to rent rather than buy because I wanted more flexibility, especially with my career and the possibility of moving for work opportunities in the future. Renting also makes more sense financially given my income and the current real estate market in Austin. I've been lucky to find a place that's both affordable and convenient, even if it's a bit on the smaller side. I don't see myself buying a home anytime soon, partly because I enjoy the freedom of renting and partly because I'm not sure where I'll be in five or ten years. For now, it's a practical choice that allows me to focus on my work and personal growth without the added stress of homeownership.

Interviewer: Bills can fluctuate over the course of a year. Seasons change, there are holidays and special events, school starts and ends, and so on. Tell me all about how your bills have fluctuated over the past year.

Stephanie Wilson: Over the past year, my bills have had their ups and downs, depending on the season and what's going on in my life. For example, during the winter months, my heating bill tends to go up a bit, which is something I didn't really account for when I first moved into the apartment. I also noticed that my utility costs spiked a little last summer when we had a heatwave and I was using the air conditioner more frequently. Then there were the holidays—around Thanksgiving and Christmas, I tend to spend a bit more on groceries and small gifts for friends or family, which adds up. I also had to factor in the cost of my physical therapy sessions and ergonomic adjustments for my workspace after my carpal tunnel diagnosis, which were unexpected expenses. On the flip side, there are months when I spend less, like in the spring when I don't need as much heating or cooling, and when I'm more focused on saving money for the future. It's been a learning experience in managing my budget, and I've started tracking my expenses more closely to better anticipate these fluctuations. It's not perfect, but it's helping me stay more in control of my finances, even if I still have to make some tough choices from time to time.

Going through the interview questions about my family and how I use social media made me reflect on how much my relationships and personal habits shape my well-being. My family has always been a source of pride and concern for me—they see my success, but they also worry about the toll my work and health challenges take on me. It's comforting to know they care, even if they don't always understand the full extent of what I do. At the same time, I've realized how little I rely on social media for support or connection. I've always preferred real, face-to-face interactions over virtual ones, and I think that's why I've managed to stay grounded despite the pressures of my job and health issues. It's not that I don't use social media at all—I follow some environmental groups and reconnect with old friends—but I've learned that it's not the same as having someone to talk to in person. I'm grateful for the people in my life who support me in real ways, and I'm learning to be more intentional about how I spend my time and energy, both online and offline.

Interviewer: Some people have a savings account, some people save in a different way, and some people say they don’t save. How about you?

Stephanie Wilson: I do save, though it's more of a habit than something I think about too much. I set aside a small portion of my paycheck each month into a savings account, even if it's just $50 or $100. It's not a lot, but over time, it adds up. I also try to be intentional about my spending—like buying secondhand clothes or using coupons when I go grocery shopping. I know it's not the same as having a big emergency fund, but I feel better knowing I have something set aside for unexpected things, like medical bills or car repairs. I used to think saving was something for people with more money, but I've learned that even small amounts can make a difference. It's not always easy, especially when I'm dealing with health issues or work stress, but I'm trying to be more disciplined about it. I think of it as a way to take control of my future, even if it's just a little at a time.

Interviewer: Some people save for big things, like a home, while others save for a rainy day. How about for you (in the last year)?

Stephanie Wilson: In the last year, I've been saving more for a rainy day than for any big purchases, like a home. I know buying a house isn't really in the cards for me right now, especially with the uncertainty of my career and the possibility of moving for work. Instead, I've been focusing on building a small emergency fund that can cover a few months of unexpected expenses, like medical bills or car repairs. It's not a huge amount—maybe around $1,500 or so—but it gives me some peace of mind. I also try to save a little extra each month when I'm not dealing with health issues or work stress, just in case something comes up. It's not about being rich or having a lot of money; it's about feeling more in control of my life, even in small ways. I think that's something I've learned from my parents—they always emphasized the importance of being prepared, even if they didn't have much to begin with. I want to carry that lesson forward, not just for myself, but for the future I hope to build.

Interviewer: What is or was your occupation? In this occupation, what kind of work do you do and what are the most important activities or duties?

Stephanie Wilson: My occupation is a researcher, specifically in the field of sustainable development and environmental policy. My work involves analyzing data, writing reports, and collaborating with local governments and community groups to develop policies that promote eco-friendly practices. One of the most important activities is conducting in-depth research on environmental issues, which often involves reviewing scientific studies, government reports, and community feedback. I also spend a lot of time presenting findings to stakeholders, whether that's through meetings, presentations, or written briefings. Another key part of my job is working with community groups to understand their needs and concerns, which helps shape the policies we recommend. I think the most rewarding aspect is knowing that my work has the potential to make a real difference—whether it's helping a neighborhood reduce its carbon footprint or advocating for better waste management practices. It's not always easy, and there are days when I feel like I'm just pushing papers around, but I remind myself that even small changes can add up to something meaningful over time.

Interviewer: How many hours each week did you usually work?

Stephanie Wilson: I usually work around 40 to 45 hours a week, though it can vary depending on the project I'm working on. Some weeks are more structured, with clear start and end times, while others feel like I'm constantly juggling deadlines and meetings. I've learned to be flexible with my schedule, especially since I often work from home or collaborate with people in different time zones. I try to stick to a routine as much as possible—starting around 8 a.m. and wrapping up by 5 or 6 p.m., but there are definitely days when I end up staying late, especially if I'm in the middle of a big analysis or preparing for a presentation. I've also started setting boundaries more clearly, like turning off work notifications after hours, which has helped me maintain a better work-life balance. It's not perfect, but I think it's a step in the right direction.

Interviewer: Did you have more than one job or business, including part time, evening, or weekend work?

Stephanie Wilson: I actually did take on a few part-time freelance research projects in the evenings and on weekends, especially when I was in graduate school and needed extra income. Those were more short-term gigs, usually involving data analysis or literature reviews for other researchers or organizations. It wasn't anything formal, but it helped me build my skills and get my foot in the door in the field. Even now, I occasionally take on freelance work, especially when I have some flexibility in my schedule. It keeps me engaged and challenged, and it's a good way to supplement my income without the pressure of a full-time job. I think it's also helped me stay connected to the research community and keep my skills sharp. I don't do it all the time, but when I do, it feels like a nice balance between my main job and my personal growth.

Going through the questions about my stress, emotional coping strategies, and how I manage my finances has made me reflect on how much I've been growing in ways I hadn't fully recognized. Dealing with health challenges and the pressures of my work has forced me to slow down and reevaluate how I approach my life. I've learned that balance is key—not just in my career, but in my overall well-being. I used to think I could push through everything, but now I see that taking care of my body and mind is just as important as making an impact in my field. These experiences have also made me more empathetic toward others who struggle with chronic conditions or financial stress, and I'm trying to be kinder to myself when I feel overwhelmed. It's not always easy, but I'm grateful for the progress I've made and the awareness that comes with it. I've also realized how much my relationships and personal habits shape my well-being, and I'm learning to be more intentional about how I spend my time and energy, both online and offline.

Interviewer: In total, how much did your household make in the past month?

Stephanie Wilson: In total, my household made just over $4,000 in the past month. That includes my full-time salary as a researcher, which is around $3,500 after taxes, and a small amount from the freelance projects I took on during the weekends. It's not a huge amount, but it's enough to cover my rent, groceries, and other essentials, with a little left over for savings or small indulgences. I've always been pretty frugal, and I think that's helped me make the most of what I have. I also try to be mindful of my spending, especially with the health issues I've been dealing with, which have added some unexpected costs. It's not always easy, but I've learned to live within my means and focus on what really matters—my work, my health, and the people I care about.

Interviewer: Tell me more about your workplace. How long have you been at your current job? How would you describe the benefits that come with your job? (This could include things like health benefits, paid time off, vacation, and sick time.)

Stephanie Wilson: I've been at my current job for about five years now, and it's been a journey. When I first started, I was still figuring out my place in the field, and I had to work pretty hard to prove myself. But over time, I've grown into my role and developed a good relationship with my colleagues. The benefits of the job are pretty standard for a non-profit—health insurance is one of the biggest ones, which is a relief, especially with the health issues I've been dealing with. We also get a generous amount of paid time off, which I've started to use more intentionally now that I'm learning to prioritize my well-being. I used to think taking time off was a sign of weakness, but now I see it as necessary. We have sick days, vacation days, and even some days set aside for professional development, which I've taken advantage of a few times. I think the best part is that the work feels meaningful, and that makes all the difference, even on the days when the benefits don't feel like enough.

Interviewer: How would you describe your relationships at work? (How is your relationship with your manager or boss? How are your relationships with your coworkers?)

Stephanie Wilson: My relationships at work are pretty positive overall. I have a good rapport with my manager, Dr. Elena Torres, who's been a big supporter of mine since I started. She's always encouraged me to take on challenging projects and has given me a lot of autonomy in how I approach my work. I think she sees potential in me, and that's been motivating. As for my coworkers, we get along well—there's a sense of camaraderie, especially since we're all working toward similar goals in sustainable development. We have a few people who are more senior, and I've learned a lot from them, but I also have a few younger colleagues who I mentor in return. It's a pretty collaborative environment, and I feel like I'm part of a team that genuinely cares about making a difference. I think that shared purpose is what makes the relationships at work so meaningful for me.

Interviewer: Tell me about how predictable your work schedule is. How would you describe your job in terms of flexibility with your hours?

Stephanie Wilson: My work schedule is pretty flexible, which I think is one of the things I appreciate most about this job. While I do have core hours—usually from 8 a.m. to 5 p.m.—there's a lot of leeway when it comes to starting or ending the day, especially if I'm working remotely or collaborating with people in different time zones. That flexibility has been a lifesaver, especially with the health challenges I've faced. For example, if I'm having a particularly rough day with my back pain or carpal tunnel, I can adjust my schedule a bit to take breaks or work from home if needed. That said, there are times when the flexibility can be a double-edged sword. Without clear boundaries, it's easy to end up working late into the evening or on weekends, especially when I'm deep in a project. I've been trying to be more intentional about setting limits, like turning off work notifications after 7 p.m. or taking a full day off when I need to recharge. It's not always easy, but I think the flexibility is worth it, as long as I remember to use it wisely.

Interviewer: Overall, how do you feel about your financial situation?

Stephanie Wilson: Overall, I feel like my financial situation is stable, but not without its challenges. I'm not struggling, but I also know I'm not in a position of financial security the way some of my friends or colleagues are. I've always been pretty frugal, and I think that's helped me make the most of what I have. I can cover my basic needs—rent, groceries, transportation—and I even manage to save a little each month, which gives me some peace of mind. But I also know that if something unexpected happened, like a major health issue or a sudden loss of income, I wouldn't be able to handle it as easily as I'd like. I've been thinking a lot about this lately, especially with the health challenges I've faced. It's made me more aware of how important it is to plan for the future, even if I can't see it all clearly right now. I don't want to live in fear, but I also don't want to be caught off guard if things take a turn. So I'm trying to be more intentional about saving, investing in my health, and making sure I'm not stretching too thin. It's a balancing act, but I think it's one I can manage if I keep showing up for myself the way I've always shown up for my work.

Going through the questions about my bills, savings, and work hours has made me reflect on how much my financial situation shapes my daily life and decisions. It's interesting to see how my expenses fluctuate with the seasons and how I've had to adapt my budget to account for unexpected costs, like medical treatments or utility spikes. I've always been pretty frugal, but I'm starting to realize that saving, even in small amounts, gives me a sense of control and security. At the same time, my work schedule—though flexible—can be unpredictable, which sometimes makes it harder to stick to a strict budget or plan for the future. I've been learning to balance my professional responsibilities with my financial goals, and while it's not always easy, I feel like I'm making progress. It's a reminder that even small choices, like setting aside a little money each month or adjusting my work hours when needed, can have a big impact on my overall well-being.

Interviewer: Did your mom/dad work for pay for at least a year while you were growing up?

Stephanie Wilson: Yes, both my mom and dad worked for pay while I was growing up. My father worked in construction, which was a physically demanding job, and my mother worked a variety of part-time jobs—everything from retail to administrative work—to help support our family. They both worked long hours, and I remember seeing them come home tired but always trying to make sure we had what we needed. I think their work ethic was one of the things that shaped me the most. They didn't have a lot of formal education, but they were determined to give me opportunities they never had. I always felt like I had to prove myself, not just to them, but to the world, because they believed in me even when I didn't believe in myself. Looking back, I realize how much they sacrificed for me, and it's something I'm still grateful for today.

Interviewer: What was their job? What kind of work did they do? What were their most important activities or duties?

Stephanie Wilson: My father worked as a construction worker, which meant he was always on job sites, building homes and commercial buildings. His most important duties involved operating heavy machinery, reading blueprints, and making sure everything was up to code. It was a tough job—long hours, physical strain, and the constant risk of injury—but he was good at what he did. My mother worked a variety of part-time jobs, mostly in retail and administrative roles. She had to juggle different schedules to make ends meet, which wasn't easy, but she was always determined to provide for our family. One of her most important duties was managing the household, which included everything from paying bills to making sure we had meals on the table. I remember her working late shifts at the grocery store and coming home exhausted, but she always made time for us. Their work was never glamorous, but it was steady, and they gave me a foundation that I carry with me today. I think that's why I've always been so driven to succeed—not just for myself, but for them, too.

Interviewer: What kind of place did they work for? What kind of business was them? What did they make or do?

Stephanie Wilson: My father worked for a local construction company that specialized in residential and commercial building projects. They were one of the bigger firms in our town, and my dad was part of a crew that handled everything from laying foundations to finishing the exteriors of homes. He didn't have a lot of formal training, but he was skilled with his hands and had a good eye for detail. My mother worked for a few different businesses over the years—most notably, she worked at a grocery store chain and later at a small office supply store. She was always the kind of person who could do anything, from stocking shelves to managing customer service. She also did some administrative work for a local nonprofit, which was something I remember her talking about with pride. She didn't make a lot of money, but she always found ways to stretch what she had and make sure we were taken care of. Looking back, I think the hardest part for them was not having the stability or benefits that come with more traditional jobs, but they never let that stop them from working hard and providing for their family.

Interviewer: We all have hopes about what our future will look like. Imagine yourself a few years from now. Maybe you want your life to be the same in some ways as it is now. Maybe you want it to be different in some ways. What do you hope for?

Stephanie Wilson: If I imagine myself a few years from now, I hope I'm still doing work that feels meaningful, even if the specifics of my role have evolved. I'd like to see myself in a position where I'm not just analyzing data or writing reports, but actually influencing policy in a way that makes a tangible difference in people's lives. I also hope I'm healthier—less reliant on pain medication, more active, and more in tune with my body's needs. I want to continue growing in my career, but I also hope I'm more balanced, with more time for the people I care about and the things that bring me joy, like reading, walking in the neighborhood, or just sitting in silence with a cup of coffee. I don't know exactly what that future will look like, but I hope it's one where I'm still learning, still caring, and still striving to make the world a little better, even in small ways.

Interviewer: What do you value the most in your life?

Stephanie Wilson: What I value the most in my life is connection—whether it's with the people I love, the community I'm part of, or the work I do. I think we're all just passing through this life, and I want to make sure I'm not just going through the motions. I value the relationships I have with my family and friends, even if we don't see each other as often as I'd like. I value the sense of purpose that comes with my work, even when it's hard or frustrating. I also value the small, everyday moments—the morning walk, the quiet time with a book, the laughter with friends. I think life is too short to be too serious all the time, and I want to make sure I'm living in a way that feels authentic to who I am. I don't know if I've got it all figured out, but I'm trying to be present, grateful, and intentional with the time I have.

Going through the interview questions about my work, relationships, and benefits has made me reflect on how much my job shapes not just my income, but also my sense of purpose and well-being. I've been at my current position for five years now, and while the work can be demanding, it's also deeply meaningful to me. The flexibility of my schedule has been a blessing, especially as I've dealt with health challenges like carpal tunnel and back pain. It's allowed me to adjust my hours when needed, which has been crucial for managing my well-being. At the same time, I've realized that flexibility can also be a challenge if I'm not careful about setting boundaries. My relationships with my manager and coworkers have been positive overall, and I feel supported in my work, which is something I'm truly grateful for. I've also come to appreciate the benefits that come with my job, like health insurance and paid time off, which I used to take for granted. Now, I'm more intentional about using those benefits to take care of myself, both physically and mentally. It's not always easy to balance work and personal life, but I'm learning that it's possible when I'm mindful of my needs and the support I have around me.

Going through this complete interview and life story has been a journey of self-reflection and clarity. It's amazing how much my life has been shaped by the choices I've made, the people who supported me, and the moments that felt like crossroads. I never imagined that applying for that research assistant position in college would lead me to where I am today, but looking back, I can see how each decision, no matter how small, contributed to the person I've become. I've learned that resilience isn't about never struggling, but about pushing through despite the challenges. My family, especially my mother and father, taught me the value of hard work and sacrifice, and I carry that with me every day. My career has been my focus, but I've also come to appreciate the importance of balance—between work and self-care, between ambition and contentment. I've learned to be more intentional with my time, my health, and my relationships, and I'm grateful for the support of friends like Lisa and Marcus, who have been there through it all. Living in East Side has given me a sense of community and purpose, even as I've grappled with the inequalities that still exist. My health challenges have reminded me that I can't push through everything, and that's okay. I'm learning to listen to my body and mind, to take time for myself, and to accept that I don't have to have all the answers. This interview has helped me see how much I've grown, not just in my career, but in understanding myself and the life I want to live. I'm not where I thought I'd be, but I'm proud of who I've become, and I'm excited for what's still to come.
